review.title: A Robust Framework for Classifying Evolving Document Streams in an Expert-Machine-Crowd Setting
review.abstract: An emerging challenge in the online classification of social media data streams is to keep the categories used for classification up-to-date. In this paper, we propose an innovative framework based on an Expert-Machine-Crowd (EMC) triad to help categorize items by continuously identifying novel concepts in heterogeneous data streams often riddled with outliers. We unify constrained clustering and outlier detection by formulating a novel optimization problem: COD-Means. We design an algorithm to solve the COD-Means problem and show that COD-Means will not only help detect novel categories but also seamlessly discover human annotation errors and improve the overall quality of the categorization process. Experiments on diverse real data sets demonstrate that our approach is both effective and efficient.

sections.heading: II. PROBLEM DEFINITION
sections.text: We get as input a data set D of documents categorized by crowdsourcing workers (not necessarily experts), or an automatic classifier into a taxonomy T = {T1,..., Tk, Z} that contains | T | = k + 1 categories. Taxonomy forms a subdivision of the documents: A-B = ∅ A, B-T, A 6 = B. We designate the categories Ti as the already existing categories defined by the expert before the data arrives, based on background knowledge. Category Z, on the other hand, is the "other" category that is used for documents that do not fit into one of the Ti categories. In practical cases for the domain in which we focus (disasters and social media), this category contains anywhere from about 10% to 30% of the messages [7]. sections.heading: V. RELATED WORK
sections.text: In general, cluster analysis methods attempt to form disjointed groups of unlabeled data elements in such a way that items within the same group are similar, while items in different groups are dissimilar. For example, such a famous cluster analysis method is k-means [11]. However, in a semi-monitored cluster approach, the algorithm uses both labeled and unlabeled data. In this particular case, the labeled data elements are used as background knowledge during the clustering process.Many works describe the use of constraints in different ways, e.g. some at group level (i.e., at item level) and others at item level (i.e., between two items) to provide background knowledge.For example, in [14] the k-mean algorithm is extended to include constraints at the instance level. However, our method, in addition to constraints at the instance level (i.e., between two item levels), detects and eliminates outliers during the cluster building process by observing cluster compacts.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: Since monitored learning systems cannot be used to identify new concepts, we use unsupervised learning techniques for this purpose. We introduced a novel cluster algorithm called COD means, which uses human and machine-categorized items as background knowledge to form constraints and identify new categories. Besides helping to identify new categories, the proposed algorithm seamlessly detects outliers from each cluster that eliminate categorization errors. Extensive experiments with real data sets show that our approach is effective and efficient.
